Confirmation of preliminary results announcement

Further to its announcement of 15 July 2019, Sports Direct confirms that the Company's audited results will be published on 26 July 2019.

The accounts and audit are at an advanced stage and the results are expected to be within the guidance issued by the Company on 13 December 2018.

BE11:21am

Vodafone’s 1Q20 results release brings two meaningful improvements to the two key investor concerns that have driven a material de-rating of Vodafone – debt and lack of top-line growth. We highlight: 1) Better 1Q20 organic service revenue growth (OSRG) of -0.2% vs company-compiled consensus -0.6% and -0.7% 4Q19 implies a faster return to top-line growth or stability than had been expected following several quarters of decline. 2) In addition, the company has announced plans to monetise its tower portfolio, potentially through a combination of IPO and tower sales, to help reduce its debt position. We believe that these actions should provide meaningful reassurance to key investor concerns. While potentially splitting out towers may have the consequence of reducing the remainder of Vodafone Group growth and FCF visibility, management action to resolve its debt position is positive in our view.

Soundbuy Abseiling sideline perhaps.........

We've been through the arguments before with regards tower spinouts releasing value, right?

red thats cos it is sale and leaseback
BE11:25am

JP Morgan:

BE11:25am

Today’s results offer many reasons to be positive, particularly against the backdrop of depressed market expectations: (1) Q1 has delivered a meaningful service revenue inflection from -0.7% in Q4 to -0.2%, (2) Management “expect the gradual recovery in service revenues to continue” which suggests Q2 will mark a return to growth, (3) Whilst KPIs are a little soft this quarter, management expect a rebound in Q2, (4) Management have announced plans to create Europe’s largest tower company. The scenario analysis within this report shows that this deal, twinned with the recently approved Liberty Global deal, could unlock significant value and see the shares re-rate as much as 50-60%.

jaws BE anything in CVSG after todays news please ?
Plato the Cook @Excell: my understanding is it's very short range or no faster than 4G
11:25 am
BE11:26am

Let me skip to the towers valuation.

LondonSalmon why AUTOTRADER so weak since mid June.... has moved tick for tick with RMV (down today post #s) which makes me think its in large part due to UK Macro/Thematic hedge?! (although both FTSE & FTSE250 moved the other way!) Any thoughts?!
BE11:27am

Our key thoughts at this early stage are as follows:
 We would prefer to see Vodafone pursue an IPO rather than a minority stake sale to PE or a strategic buyer. We believe this would provide a better see-through value and moreover would provide a clearer vehicle through which the group could pursue tower acquisitions or mergers
 We would expect Vodafone to announce some selective, small scale, tower disposals in the coming quarters prior to the formation of this entity
 Vodafone is also likely to continue announcing both active and passive tower sharing deals in the meantime, with this helping to accelerate the group’s 5G network build, whilst also offering substantial opex and capex synergies.
 Whilst the proceeds of tower sales will helpfully support group deleveraging, we actually think the key attraction of this deal will be to unlock the "hidden" value within Vodafone's heavily depressed share price. Note that our SoTP based valuation offers 67% upside, highlighting the deep value presented by the group’s shares.

Excel Developer "5G Will Go Rural But With Less CapacityThe multi-gigabit speeds and massive capacity you hear about with 5G is by and large an urban phenomenon, driven by the huge bandwidths of millimeter-wave spectrum, which doesn't travel very far. Rural areas will get a form of 5G called "low-band" or "sub-6" 5G, which will have less capacity but still have extremely low latency and be able to work with massive networks of industrial sensors."
red cellnex
BE11:27am

So taking a Mar-21 year pro-forma .....

11:27 am
BE11:27am

... Vodafone’s proportionate EV would be €82.1bn. Net debt is €45.5bn implying leverage of 2.9x. This leaves €36.6bn in equity. Based on our forecasts we estimate that Vodafone pro-forma for this deal trades on a proportionate EV/EBITDA multiple of 5.7x, EV/OpFCF of 11.0x and an EFCF yield of 13.8%.

BE11:28am

In the scenario that Vodafone IPOs its European tower portfolio we assume a trading EV/EBITDA multiple of 17-23x (the range of European tower benchmarks). We also assume Vodafone's tower portfolio would be levered at 4x EBITDA.

BE11:28am

On this basis, we find post a tower IPO, the Vodafone rump would be left looking extremely cheap on all key valuation metrics. Notably the company would trade on an EV/EBITDA multiple of just 4.7-5.0x, an EV/OpFCF multiple of 9.3-10.0x and a staggeringly cheap EFCF yield of 17.2-20.5%.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

It's like creating money from thin air!

BE11:28am

I see no reason why these supermarkets shouldn't sell their real estate portfolios then ..... no, wait sorry, wrong RNS ....

Plato the Cook As ever, the problem will be sufficient capacity in the backhaul/backbone networks
BE11:29am

In a blue sky scenario it is conceivable that Vodafone's rump equity value could close to double, still offering a very attractive roughly 10% EFCF yield, and this would be sufficient to re-rate Vodafone’s group equity value by 55-60%.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

As is the equity market this morning, we are pleased that (i) VOD's service revenue performance in 1Q FY20 exceeded consensus expectations, and (ii) partly in response to unsolicited approaches, VOD is now preparing various ways to monetise its European tower assets in the next 18 months. However, we believe (i) VOD exceeded consensus expectations mainly because its less important assets outperformed, and (ii) at this stage, it is not clear that monetising tower assets at premium multiples will not also hurt OpCo EBITDA. In any case, we believe our and consensus forecasts for VOD will not change meaningfully after today. Therefore, our Target Price and recommendation remain 135p/share and HOLD, respectively.

BE11:33am

VOD TowerCo. In November 2018, VOD said that by creating its own TowerCo with its own dedicated management team the group will drive cost efficiencies and boost tenancies. VOD's CEO also said "when you start thinking about disposing of, let's say, a minority stake in towers, you have to start thinking about, well, if you've got 5% or 6% cost of funding, and we've got 2.5%, you're internalising that cost into our model. So the attractive multiple needs to be high for us to do that". Today, VOD reported receiving unsolicited offers of "north of 20x EBITDA" for some of its tower assets. This, of course, is great. But we still need to determine how much extra opex VOD will incur for occupying towers sold to a third-party that has borrowed at 5% or 6% to pay VOD greater than 20x EBITDA for an equity stake in these towers.

BE11:33am

Bingo.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:41am

Rightmove results are a bit mixed. On the one hand the headline financials are very much in line, and there is unlikely to be dramatic moves in consensus for the year. This is still resilient in a tough market. On the other hand, UK agent numbers are seeing accelerating declines (down 3% sequentially) and the core UK agent revenue line is only growing 6% - a major slowdown vs the last few years. And then they have done a small bit of M&A – strategically sensible on the face of it but a change in tone from giving all the cash back to shareholders. The key will be how they communicate at the meeting around 2020 – this is at 9am. We are Underweight the shares and believe 25x P/E is too expensive for a business slowing towards mid single digit growth, with little further room for margin expansion.

A. M. (to my untrained eye, sale-and-lease-back has the look and feel of PE about it)

And Peel Hunt.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Interims – ahead but agency numbers fall Rightmove once again delivered a set of resilient results, which beat our forecasts by c4%. However, the key concern is that agency numbers have further contracted by 3% since the start of the year. A strong rise in new home developers by 10% has made for the agency weakness but all signs are pointing to a challenged housing market. A boost could come from improved housing policies from our new prime minister but we will have to wait and see. Currently, Rightmove’s shares trade on 26x FY19 PER. We believe the risks ahead are not priced into the current valuation. Reduce.

BE11:43am

Credit Suisse as well.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The release includes financials slightly ahead of cons (revs +1.2%, u/l op profit +0.9%), as tends to be customary for the group. Within the mix the group has seen an acceleration of the trends seen in 2H18 with meaningful agency membership declines offset by New Home membership strength and strong ARPA across the group. Whilst group level KPIs were broadly in-line (although membership slightly weak offset by ARPA) we see the accelerating decline in agency membership (-560 in 1H19 vs –257 in 2H18) as an increasing problem. We have concerns that the New Home strength is temporary (aided by a onetime GDPR spending related uplift and elongation of listing duration) whilst weaker agency membership is potentially set to stick around through 2020. We believe the print this morning will further raise market concerns around the cyclical positioning of the group.

GBKrona Talking of Rightmove, Toscafund are increasing their stake in Purplebricks
Excel Developer @VV75: I love macro, it's just I've given up asking. At least Bryce doesn't mind us posting macro content here in readers' corner.

FATDAZ If I was Vodafone I would list the tower biz in the US simply on premise that American Tower massively out performed vod over the last year ....
BE11:46am

Yes, yes, okay. Let's talk inflation expectations.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

During his press conference yesterday, Draghi hinted at a decline in inflation expectations from the ECB survey
of professional forecasters. The 3Q data, released today but known by the ECB in advance, show a sharp fall in
expectations across all horizons. The 1-year ahead inflation expectation measure is down 0.21%-pt to 1.34%.
The 2-year ahead measure is down 0.11%-pt to 1.49%. And the 5-year ahead measure is down 0.06%-pt to
1.74%.
The anchoring of expectations is key for the ECB, since inflation should print in line with inflation expectations
when the output gap is closed and in the absence of shocks (commodity prices, taxes, or the currency). The ECB
thus pays a lot of attention to longer-term expectations with regard to its inflation objective. The news in this
respect is not encouraging. The slide in the 5-year ahead measure since the start of the year has been significant,
and this measure is now at an all-time low. The outcome of the 3Q survey is furthermore worse than it first
looks. The 3Q longer-term survey asked respondents to forecast inflation in 2024, while the 2Q longer-term
survey referred to 2023.

BE11:46am

This is JP Morgan.

BE11:46am

Market-based inflation expectations have also declined significantly since the start of the year. The 5Yx5Y swap
rate is down from 1.55% to 1.31%. Although this measure of inflation expectation is lower than the 5-year
ahead ECB survey, the intensity of the decline has been of a similar magnitude (last chart). We had highlighted
in a recent piece that market-based inflation expectations could help forecasting the ECB survey (details here).
The latest ECB print is now aligned with the signal of the 5Yx5Y swap rate.
The decline in the ECB expectation measures is taking place as headline inflation has been declining. We
showed earlier that the sensitivity of expectations to headline inflation has increased over time, pointing to a deanchoring
challenge for the ECB (details here). Today’s data reinforce this point. The decline in long-term
inflation expectations, in particular, is a concern since the ECB has already used a lot of ammunition.

marktime Despite these bad bits of housing market news builders are stronger today, pending a statement from the new government?
11:48 am
BE11:48am

Now like me you're probably wondering, what curve does JPM use to model Euro area core inflation?

BE11:48am

We use a Phillip curve model to forecast Euro area core inflation. This model uses a weighted average of the ECB 2-year and 5-year ahead inflation expectation measures, and assumes that inflation expectations will increase very modestly to reach 1.80% by the end of 2020.

BE11:49am

Based on this assumption, our model forecasts that core inflation will rise gradually to reach 1.4%oya in 4Q20 (in line with our official forecast). If we assume instead that inflation expectations remain stuck at the current level (1.66% according to our 1/3 and 2/3 weights), core inflation would only reach 1.3%oya in 4Q19. Today’s release thus creates a bit of downside risks around our core inflation forecast.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Or Goldman, if you like?

BE11:50am

Given the round-trip in rates, the market is still pricing a decent degree of easing. For rate cuts, we estimate there is around 12bp priced for the September meeting, and around 23bp of cuts priced at the low point of the curve. Risk-reward is relatively balanced here, although we do expect pricing to richen somewhat into the September meeting given our expectation for a 20bp cut. For the pricing of asset purchases, we rely on our QE pricing framework, which aims to back out expected balance sheet expansion from movement in sovereign yields in Europe.

BE11:50am

After the rally into today’s meeting we estimate the market is now pricing closer to 150-200bn worth of balance sheet expansion. This means the risk-reward has shifted – in the absence of a clearer signal today on the ECB’s willingness to relax its constraints on the purchase program, the market’s ability to price significantly more balance sheet expansion will be limited. This means the QE trade has a little more room to run, but it is now likely that returns will come from carry rather than capital gains. In the cross-section, our assessment has not changed – the best risk-adjusted carry still comes from Spain and Portugal, despite recent political noise in Spain.

Soundbuy Sure I read something about 1st time buyers and the ability to access pensions early........
11:50 am
BE11:50am

For core rates we think the outlook is still bullish, but prefer to express QE trades in periphery carry given a more balanced risk-reward. Bund yields are not far from the fresh lows made after the initial ECB statement. And the incoming macro data, such as the disappointment in the European PMIs and the German IFO, continues to support low yields. Using our macro cross-asset framework, there remains little dislocation in core rates against macro factors, and over the last two weeks pricing has richened due to a deterioration in all factors – growth, inflation, and policy signals are all pointing to lower rates. Without more meaningful evidence that growth is picking up we are unlikely to see a sell-off as we approach the September ECB meeting.

Soundbuy Plus the usual stamp duty nonsense
BE11:50am

Finally, after initially moving higher, EUR inflation swaps retraced most of their rally today. The initial ECB statement highlighted the ‘symmetry’ of the inflation aim – a new signal from the Governing Council. While this statement of intent is a useful guide to the stance of policy, and was certainly reiterated by President Draghi, without action it is likely to have little lasting impact on inflation markets. This language is far from a commitment to average inflation targeting and would need to be operationalised with direct action (for example, through something like an ‘inflation threshold’) before it would drive a recovery in inflation markets.

BE11:51am

BE11:57am

Here's BMO.

Blank canvas thanks Bryce for everything today and this week. enjoy the weekend
BE11:57am

Kingmaker Abdicates? Our theory about Mr Agarwal's stake was that he was hoping to act as kingmaker in the event that a third party took a liking to Anglo American's copper assets. If a third party had made a takeover approach for Anglo American, he could have voted in favour of a transaction in exchange for the opportunity to buy the South African and perhaps diamond businesses at a fair market value. This is now all moot, but Mr Agarwal, could have debt debt financed an acquisition of the high cash flow but low multiple South African operations.
• Impact? We have previously written on the attractiveness of Anglo American's copper assets to third parties, particularly to a larger peer such as Rio Tinto*, which is not in control of its copper destiny, in our opinion (Escondida is run by BHP*, and the vacillations of the Mongolian government continues to create political uncertainty around Oyu Tolgoi). However, the dramatic rise in Anglo American's share price and the understandable board and management deal reticence, a legacy of the valuedestructive
super-cycle mega deals (see our related note), meant any approach was unlikely.
• Action? Anglo American's shares have sold off today, which simply reflects the reported price (£21 according to Bloomberg) at which Agarwal is exiting his stake.
Our view is that Anglo American remains the best placed of the diversifieds from an operational perspective with attractive near-term valuation multiples and the potential to Increase productivity and earnings through technological innovation. We continue to rate AAL Outperform.

BE12:02pm

The company has confirmed the improvement in trading in H2 and there are no changes to our forecasts, albeit we see risks to the upside. EBITDA improved by c12% last year, helped by 4.3% LFL growth in the Practices division, with H2 improving by c30% after a 4% reduction in H1.

BE12:03pm

The shares have now responded to the improving trends and recognition that CVS continues to be an attractive business in a consolidating industry. However, the EV/EBITDA of 12.6x to June 2020E is still below recent transactions for larger business, which have been completed at 15-18x EBITDA.

jaws BE thank you

BE12:06pm

LFL growth in the Practices division was 4.3% for the FY (vs 4.4% in the 11m
to June). The number for the core Practices division in the RNS of 3.8% includes
some other activities, such as the buying group. We focus on the Practices
themselves as they are the core driver for group profitability. The LFL growth is
close to the 4.7% average for the last five years.
Adjusted EBITDA is expected to be in line with forecasts, which we upgraded
by 6% in June (nb our number excludes acquisition transaction costs and sharebased
payments).
Net debt was c£102m at year end, which was lower than our £109m forecast and
gives net debt:EBITDA of 1.9x. CVS continues to be highly cash generative,
with the FCF forecast to be c£37m and ND:EBITDA reducing to 1.2x in 2020E.
